@GCAT01Living It's a good game! I just could't enjoy some of the content. As for the plot... it's ok to have no plot, but my brain always looks for some hints of a story, I really thought it was "some experiment went wrong" or "we found an ancient artefact" scenario :)

As you may guess, There were NO answers... Can't say that I'm really disappointed, but the concept "It can mean all the deep philosophical thoughts of your choie... or nothing at all" is not my cup of tea. BUT. It's still all about puzzles, and they were mostly good. 5/5

positioning of the player instead of logic, and also there is no plot, or story, or characters... I just wondered the whole time "Does this have any meaning? Those statues must be here for a reason! Audio logs must tell the story! All the answers are on that mountain!" 4/5

"The Witness", on the other hand, was a good game for me. I liked the majority of the puzzles, everything looks beautiful, though it takes time to get used to the visual style. The only two things, that I didn't like was that some puzzles need perception and the very precise 3/5 https://t.co/9p6g9lZsDY

"The Turing Test" didn't impress me at all. The puzzles were not bad, but not really challenging, and the plot... well, I wish there were no plot at all. You know, if the plot is simple and predictable - it's ok for a puzzle game, but this ending was one of the worst ever. 2/5
I really like that good feeling of working brain, so I thought it might be a good idea to look for more puzzle games - recently I completed "The Turing Test" (AI theme again!) and "The Witness". 1/5

@DahkurArt Thank you so much!! Floor mosaics and statues in the game are incredibly accurate recreations of existing ones, I love this fact. Ir really worth playing, it's one of my two "best games ever". As far as I know, it's available on many platforms, including PC.

In fact, when I played it for the first time it made me rethink everything about my life and beliefs. Those thoughts were depressing and difficult, and so were the conclusions, but sometimes we need to go through it to change and evolve. 7/7

If you ask me, what is the best story about AI ever - I'll name "The Talos Principle". It's much more than just puzzle solving, there are so many philosophical questions about AI, and also about human nature, soul, mortality, faith. 6/7

I also loved Alexandra Drennan, we've never seen her in the game and yet her thoughts in the journals and her time capsules are unforgettable. I wish I could paint her too, maybe sometime in the future. 5/7

and in "Road to Gehenna" he saves everyone. In my ending he died, sacrificing himself so no one is left behind, and his death was the most terrifying thing I've experienced in games - somehow It felt so real... 4/7

I can't express the feeling I had when the player actually meets him at the top of the tower. Uriel4, on the other hand, represent faith and Elohim, but I see also some similarities to The Shepherd - he also stayed to help others, 3/7

The Shepherd is a true hero, and we know it only by some QR-codes. How many lines do you need to like a character? It was enough for me. I think, he was even more important, then the player's character, and it's so sad he didn't make it to the reality. 2/7 https://t.co/ewCwX4mQe9
I finally finished this painting - The Shepherd, Milton and Uriel4 from "The Talos Principle". I was really impressed by those characters. 1/7 @TalosPrinciple @Croteam https://t.co/ugDnwJciT2
Well, it's good to remember the ending of "The Road to Gehenna" - the most beautiful scene I've ever seen in games... though my ending was not only beautiful, but also scary. 2/2
